discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
You can only order by column names from the first select query

Correct answer is BCD.
The ORDER BY clause does not recognize the column names of the second SELECT query. So,

choices.E: Tables in the defining query of a view must always exist in order to create the view.
choices.A: The WITH CHECK clause prevents certain rows from being updated or inserted in the underlying table through the view.
choices.D: Views can be updated without the need to re-grant privileges on the view.
choices.B: The WITH CHECK clause prevents certain rows from being displayed when querying the view.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
AD is correct
C and E also correct?

comments.content:
C - Views can be indexed. FALSE 
Only materialised views can be indexed: 
https://asktom.oracle.com/pls/apex/asktom.search?tag=indexes-on-view
E - Tables in the defining query of a view must always exist in order to create the view. FALSE: 

Usually, you create a new view based on existing tables. However, sometimes, you may want to create a view based on the tables that you will create later or the tables that you don’t have sufficient privileges to access at the time of creating the view. In these cases, you can use the FORCE option.
https://www.oracletutorial.com/oracle-view/oracle-create-view/

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about views? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: D is incorrect, there is a missing single quote before the (||) operator

Selected Answer: BD
A. SELECT 'The first_name is " || first_name || " FROM (select 'user' first_name from dual); --O/P = ORA-00923: FROM keyword not found where expected
B. SELECT 'The first_name is ''' || first_name || '''' FROM (select 'user' first_name from dual); --O/P = The first_name is 'user'
C. SELECT 'The first_name is ''' || first_name || ''' FROM (select 'user' first_name from dual); --O/P = ORA-00923: FROM keyword not found where expected
D. SELECT 'The first_name is ' || first_name || '' FROM (select 'user' first_name from dual); --O/P = The first_name is user
E. SELECT 'The first_name is \" || first_name || '\" FROM (select 'user' first_name from dual); --O/P = ORA-24450: Cannot pre-process OCI statement

Selected Answer: BD
BD for me

questions.question_text: Which two are true about unused columns? (Choose two.)

choices.C: You can specify multiple column names in an ALTER TABLE...SET UNUSED statement.
choices.A: Setting an indexed column to unused results in an error.
choices.B: You can query the data dictionary to see the names of unused columns.
choices.D: If you set all the columns of a table to unused, the table is automatically dropped.
choices.E: CASCADE CONSTRAINTS must be specified when setting a column to unused if that column is referenced in a constraint on another column.

discussion.content: C and D

Selected Answer: CE
CE is correct you can see number of unused columns but not their names in the data dictionary

comments.content: when you query the dba_unused_col_tabs view which displays a list of all tables with un-used columns, including counts of the number of columns within a table that are unused but it will not show the names of the unused columns so B is wrong

discussion.content:
B C E are all correct according to Oracle "SET UNUSED Clause"
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/23/sqlrf/ALTER-TABLE.html#GUID-552E7373-BF93-477D-9DA3-B2C9386F2877

Selected Answer: CE
CE ARE CORRECT.

comments.content:
C is correct, you can specify multiple columns in a single alter statement 
eg: ALTER TABLE EMPLOYEES SET UNUSED (JOB_ID, COMMISSION_PCT);

discussion.content: All are wrong except E
Correct answer B,E

Selected Answer: BD
A: Incorrect: INITCAP changes the first character of the extracted last name to uppercase and the rest to lowercase. However, this does not work for "MC" because INITCAP would change it to "Mc."
B:Correct: This extracts the last name and matches it directly against "Mc%" (case-sensitive). This works because "Mc" is explicitly matched.
D: Correct: UPPER ensures that both the extracted last name and the pattern are converted to uppercase, making the comparison case-insensitive. This matches both "Mc" and "MC."

Selected Answer: AD
AD is correct LIKE is case sensitive
AD tested 100% guarantee

questions.question_text:
Examine the data in the CUST_NAME column of the CUSTOMERS table:

//IMG//


You want to display the CUST_NAME values where the last name starts with Mc or MC.

Which two WHERE clauses give the required result? (Choose two.)
